description: Sit on the floor with both knees bent at 90 degrees. Your front shin should be parallel to your body, and your back leg should be rotated behind you with the shin also at 90 degrees. Sit up tall and lean forward slightly over your front leg to increase the stretch in your front hip and glute. Keep your chest up. Hold, then carefully switch the position of your legs and repeat on the other side.
Rolling ab wheel forward from kneeling position. Advanced core exercise requiring significant strength and control.

Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. Instead of hanging completely relaxed, actively pull your shoulder blades down and together, engaging your lats and upper back. Hold this engaged position. This strengthens the muscles involved in pulling while also improving shoulder stability. Alternate between active and passive hanging.

Lie face down with one leg extended out to the side and a foam roller positioned under your inner thigh. Support your weight on your forearms and opposite leg. Roll from just above your knee to your groin area, pausing on tender spots. This can be uncomfortable - breathe through it and adjust pressure as needed. Avoid rolling directly over the groin. Switch legs and repeat.

Lie face down with one leg extended out to the side and a lacrosse ball positioned under your inner thigh. Support your weight on your forearms and opposite leg. Apply pressure by relaxing into the ball. You can make small movements or hold on tender spots. This provides deeper, more targeted pressure than foam rolling. Be gentle near the groin area. Switch legs and repeat.

Start in a quadruped position (all fours). Spread your knees wide apart while keeping your ankles in line with your knees. Rock your hips back toward your heels, then forward. The movement should create a stretch in your inner thighs. Keep your spine neutral and move slowly. This provides a gentle, controlled adductor stretch.

Sit with one leg extended. Use your toes to "write" the letters of the alphabet in the air, moving only from the ankle joint. This takes your ankle through its full range of motion in multiple directions. Complete the alphabet, then switch ankles. This exercise is great for ankle mobility and rehabilitation.

Stand with feet hip-width apart. Keeping your heels on the ground, bounce gently by flexing and pointing your toes, creating small pulses. This should be a quick, rhythmic movement. You can also do this one leg at a time. This helps warm up the calves and ankle joints.

Sit or stand and lift one foot off the ground. Rotate your ankle, making large circles with your toes. Complete all reps in one direction, then reverse. Focus on moving through the full range of motion. This mobilizes the ankle joint in all directions. Repeat on the other ankle.

Sit or lie down with legs extended. Point your toes away from you (plantarflexion), then flex your toes back toward you (dorsiflexion). Move in a smooth, controlled rhythm. This pumps blood through the lower leg and mobilizes the ankle joint through its primary range of motion. Great for warming up or after long periods of sitting.

Stand with feet hip-width apart. Roll your weight from the outside edges of your feet to the inside edges, creating a rocking motion. Keep your knees soft and let your ankles move through their range of motion. This helps mobilize the ankle joints through inversion and eversion. Move slowly and controlled.
Lying leg raise with ankle weights for added resistance. Progressive overload option for lower ab development.

Stand with feet hip-width apart. Extend both arms straight out to the sides at shoulder height. Make small controlled circles, gradually increasing the size. Complete all reps circling forward, then reverse direction for the same number of reps. Keep your core engaged and avoid arching your lower back.

Start in child's pose (sitting back on your heels, arms extended forward). Keep one hand planted and make large circles with the other arm, lifting it up and around. Focus on rotating through your upper back. Complete all reps in one direction, then reverse. Switch arms and repeat. This mobilizes the thoracic spine and shoulder together.

Stand with feet hip-width apart. Extend both arms overhead. Make small controlled circles with your arms, gradually increasing the size. Complete all reps circling forward, then reverse direction. This mobilizes the shoulders while stretching the lats. Keep your core engaged and avoid arching your lower back excessively.

Stand with arms extended in front of you at shoulder height. Open your arms wide to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then bring them back to the starting position. Move in a controlled rhythm. You should feel your chest stretching as you open your arms. This helps counteract rounded shoulder posture.
Chin up with machine assistance. The underhand grip makes it slightly easier than pullups, good for building toward unassisted chin ups.
Dip with machine assistance counterbalancing a portion of your body weight. Allows beginners to build strength toward full bodyweight dips.
Neutral grip pullup with machine assistance. The comfortable grip position makes it accessible while building back strength.
Pullup with machine assistance reducing the amount of bodyweight lifted. Allows beginners to build strength toward unassisted pullups.
Wide grip pullup with machine assistance. Helps develop lat width while building toward unassisted wide grip pullups.
Face pull using resistance band. Portable option for rear delt and upper back work with variable resistance.
Glute bridge with resistance band across hips. Provides progressive resistance through the movement, perfect for glute activation and burnout sets.
Hammer curl using resistance band. Portable option for targeting biceps and forearms with variable resistance.
Hip thrust using resistance band around hips anchored behind you. Provides variable resistance with peak tension at full hip extension.
Lateral raise using resistance band. Portable option for side delt work with progressive resistance as band stretches.

Hold a resistance band in front of you at chest height with arms extended, hands about shoulder-width apart. Keep arms straight and pull the band apart by moving your hands out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Return to the starting position with control. Focus on keeping shoulders down and back, avoiding shrugging.
Single arm face pull with resistance band. Addresses rear delt imbalances with portable equipment.
Single leg hip thrust with band resistance. Variable resistance increases tension at lockout while working each glute independently.
Back extension holding a barbell across the back. Significantly increases loading for advanced lower back strength development.
Classic back squat with barbell positioned on the upper traps. One of the most effective compound movements for building lower body strength and mass.
Classic bent over row with barbell. Fundamental back builder requiring hip hinge position to target the entire back musculature.
Classic standing bicep curl with straight barbell. The fundamental bicep exercise for building arm mass and strength.
Deadlift starting with the barbell elevated on blocks or plates (typically 2-6 inches). Reduces range of motion to overload the top portion of the movement and build lockout strength.
Back squat where you sit back onto a box or bench at the bottom position. Develops posterior chain strength and teaches proper hip hinge mechanics.
Bulgarian split squat with barbell across the back. Requires excellent balance and core stability, allowing for heavier loading than dumbbell variations.
Bench press with hands positioned closer than shoulder width. Increases tricep involvement while still working the chest, excellent for building lockout strength.
The king of posterior chain exercises. Feet hip-width apart, hands outside knees, lifting the barbell from the floor to standing position. Builds total body strength and muscle mass.
Bench press on a decline (head lower than hips). Emphasizes the lower chest and allows for heavier loads due to favorable biomechanics.
Deadlift performed while standing on an elevated platform (1-4 inches). Increases range of motion, particularly strengthening the bottom position and improving off-the-floor speed.
The classic bench press performed on a flat bench. King of upper body pressing exercises for building chest, shoulder, and tricep strength and mass.
Forward lunge with barbell across the back. Requires excellent balance and core stability, allowing for heavier loading than dumbbell variations.
Front raise with barbell. Allows for heavier loading of the front delts compared to dumbbell variations.
Front squat with barbell racked across the front deltoids and clavicles. Emphasizes quadriceps and requires greater core stability and upright torso position.
Hip extension performed lying flat on the floor with barbell across hips. Similar to hip thrust but with reduced range of motion and easier setup.
Hip hinge with barbell on back, bowing forward at the hips while maintaining straight legs. Develops posterior chain strength and teaches proper hip hinge mechanics.
Traditional hack squat with barbell held behind the legs. Emphasizes quadriceps and requires significant grip strength and balance.
Hip thrust with upper back elevated on a bench and barbell across the hips. The gold standard for glute development, allowing for heavy loading through full hip extension.
Bench press on an incline (typically 30-45 degrees). Emphasizes the upper chest and front deltoids more than flat pressing.
Skullcrusher performed on an incline bench. The angle provides additional stretch on the triceps.
Advanced squat variation with barbell held overhead in a wide snatch grip. Requires exceptional mobility, stability, and core strength throughout the entire kinetic chain.
Overhead tricep extension with straight barbell. Emphasizes the long head of the triceps through overhead positioning.
Bent over row with barbell starting from the floor each rep. Emphasizes explosive power and requires strict form with torso parallel to the ground.
Bicep curl on preacher bench with arms supported at an angle. Isolates biceps by eliminating momentum and shoulder involvement.
Overhead press using leg drive to initiate the movement. Allows for heavier loads than strict pressing while building explosive power.
Deadlift starting from pins in a power rack, typically at knee height or just below. Allows for heavy overloading of the upper portion of the deadlift while reducing lower back fatigue.
Bicep curl with overhand grip. Emphasizes the brachioradialis and forearm extensors while still working the biceps.
Reverse lunge with barbell on back. The backward stepping pattern tends to be more stable than forward lunges while allowing for heavy loading.
Hip hinge movement starting from standing position with slight knee bend maintained throughout. The barbell travels down the thighs to mid-shin, emphasizing hamstring stretch and eccentric control.
Row performed lying face down on an elevated bench. Eliminates lower back involvement and prevents cheating through body momentum.
Good morning performed while seated on a bench with barbell on back. Removes leg involvement to isolate the lower back and hip hinge pattern.
Overhead press performed seated with back support. Isolates the shoulders and removes leg drive, allowing focus on pure pressing strength.
Classic trap shrug with barbell. Fundamental exercise for building trap mass and upper back thickness.
Unilateral good morning balancing on one leg. Significantly increases balance and stability demands while targeting each side independently.
Unilateral hip thrust with barbell. Addresses strength imbalances and requires significant core stability to prevent rotation.
Unilateral Romanian deadlift balancing on one leg while the other extends behind for counterbalance. Challenges stability and addresses strength imbalances while heavily engaging the core.
Lying tricep extension lowering barbell toward forehead or behind head. Highly effective for tricep mass building with controlled movement.
Deadlift with an extra-wide grip, requiring greater range of motion. Heavily targets the upper back and traps while developing pulling strength for Olympic lifts.
Shrug with wide snatch grip requiring greater range of motion. Emphasizes trap development for Olympic lifting movements.
Standing calf raise with barbell across the back, typically performed on a raised platform. Requires balance and core stability while allowing for progressive overload.
Standing overhead press with barbell. A fundamental compound movement requiring full-body stability and coordination for overhead strength.
Deadlift variation with minimal knee bend, emphasizing hamstring stretch and hip hinge. Excellent for building hamstring flexibility and strength through a full range of motion.
Wide-stance deadlift with hands inside the knees. Places greater emphasis on glutes and adductors while reducing range of motion and lower back stress compared to conventional stance.
Vertical pull lifting barbell toward chin with narrow grip. Develops shoulders and traps with pulling motion.
Walking lunges with barbell on back. Advanced variation requiring exceptional balance, core stability, and leg strength to maintain control while moving.
Upright row with wider than normal grip. Reduces shoulder impingement risk while still targeting delts and traps.

Start on all fours with knees hovering an inch off the ground. Crawl forward by moving opposite hand and foot together, keeping your hips low and core engaged. This is both a mobility drill and core activation exercise. You can also crawl backward or sideways. Maintain a flat back and controlled breathing throughout.

Stand tall and clasp your hands together behind your back with arms straight. Gently lift your hands up and away from your body, keeping your chest up and shoulders down. You should feel a stretch across the front of your shoulders and chest. Avoid leaning forward or arching your lower back excessively. Hold the position, breathing steadily.
Back extension using only body weight on a hyperextension bench. Accessible exercise for building lower back endurance and preventing injury.
Dynamic crunch with alternating knee-to-elbow rotation. Engages entire core with emphasis on obliques through rotational movement.
Single-leg squat variation with rear foot elevated on a bench or box. Excellent for developing unilateral leg strength, balance, and addressing muscle imbalances without external load.
Leg raise using captain's chair with back and forearms supported. Provides stability while isolating the abs and hip flexors.
Underhand grip pullup with palms facing you. Increases bicep involvement compared to standard pullups while still building back strength.
Side plank variation with top leg elevated on bench. Intensely targets hip adductors while building lateral core strength.
Classic abdominal crunch lifting shoulders off the ground. Fundamental core exercise isolating the rectus abdominis.
Crunch performed on decline bench with feet secured. Increases difficulty and range of motion compared to flat crunches.
Pushup with feet elevated on a bench or box. Increases difficulty and emphasizes upper chest and shoulders due to the decline angle.
Pushup with hands forming a diamond shape beneath the chest. Dramatically increases tricep activation while still engaging the chest.
Bodyweight dip on parallel bars. Excellent compound movement for building chest and tricep strength using your own body weight.
Step forward into a lunge position and return to start. Fundamental unilateral movement for building leg strength, balance, and coordination without external load.
Basic glute bridge lying on the floor. Fundamental glute exercise requiring no equipment, excellent for activation, warm-ups, or high-rep work.
Hanging from bar and raising legs toward parallel or higher. Advanced core exercise building ab strength and grip endurance.
Hip thrust with upper back on a bench using only body weight. Great for learning the movement pattern or for high-rep glute activation work.
Pushup with hands elevated on a bench or box. Reduces difficulty, making it accessible for beginners building toward standard pushups.
Horizontal row pulling yourself up to a bar set at waist height. Excellent bodyweight back exercise and prerequisite for pullups.
Side-to-side lunge targeting the frontal plane of motion. Strengthens adductors and abductors while improving hip mobility and lateral movement patterns.
Lying flat and raising legs toward ceiling. Accessible leg raise variation for building lower ab strength.
Pullup with palms facing each other using parallel handles. Shoulder-friendly grip position that balances lat and bicep involvement.

Kneeling hamstring curl where you lower your torso toward the ground using eccentric hamstring strength. Extremely effective for hamstring development and injury prevention, particularly for athletes.
Pushup in an inverted V position with hips elevated. Emphasizes shoulders and serves as a progression toward handstand pushups.
Standard front plank holding body in straight line on forearms and toes. Fundamental isometric core exercise building stability and endurance.
Classic overhand grip pullup. The gold standard bodyweight back exercise for building lat width and upper body pulling strength.
Classic pushup in prone position. Fundamental bodyweight exercise for building chest, shoulder, and tricep strength requiring no equipment.
Step backward into a lunge and return to start. Often easier on the knees than forward lunges and provides better control of the movement.
Seated rotational movement twisting torso side to side. Develops oblique strength and rotational core control.
Lateral plank balancing on one forearm with body in straight line. Emphasizes obliques and lateral core stability.
Unilateral hip thrust using body weight only. Challenges balance and stability while isolating each glute independently.
Unilateral leg raise working one leg at a time. Addresses imbalances and allows focus on each side independently.

standard_name: Bodyweight Single Leg Standing Calf Raise
description: Unilateral bodyweight calf raise on a step or raised surface. Excellent for building calf strength and balance without equipment.
Standing calf raise using only body weight, typically performed on a step or raised surface. Accessible anywhere and effective for building calf endurance and definition.
Continuous forward lunges, stepping through each rep. Dynamic movement that builds leg strength, endurance, and coordination while covering distance.
Pullup with hands positioned wider than shoulder width. Emphasizes lat width and reduces bicep involvement compared to standard grip.
Pushup with hands positioned wider than shoulder width. Increases chest activation and stretch compared to standard pushups.

Sit on the floor and bring the soles of your feet together, letting your knees fall out to the sides. Hold your feet or ankles and sit up tall. Gently press your knees toward the floor using your elbows, or simply let gravity pull them down. You should feel a stretch in your inner thighs and groin. Keep your back straight and lean forward from the hips to deepen the stretch.
Bent over reverse fly using cable machine with crossed cables. Provides constant tension for rear delt development.
Bicep curl using cable machine with straight or EZ bar attachment. Provides constant tension throughout the entire range of motion.
Lat pulldown with close grip attachment. Emphasizes lower lats and allows for greater range of motion than wide grip.
Concentration curl using low cable pulley. Combines the isolation of concentration curls with constant cable tension.
Kneeling crunch pulling cable rope attachment toward floor. Provides constant tension throughout the movement for ab development.
Decline cable fly using high pulleys. Targets lower chest with constant tension for complete development.
Rear delt exercise pulling rope attachment toward the face with elbows high. Essential for shoulder health and balanced upper body development.
Chest fly using cable machine at mid-height. Provides constant tension throughout the entire range of motion for consistent chest activation.
Front raise using cable machine with rope or straight bar. Provides constant tension throughout the movement.
Hammer curl using rope attachment on cable machine. Provides constant tension with neutral grip for comprehensive arm development.
Incline cable fly using low pulleys. Targets upper chest with constant tension throughout the movement.
Lateral raise using cable machine. Provides constant tension throughout the movement for consistent shoulder activation.
Lat pulldown on cable machine with standard wide bar. Fundamental back exercise for building lat width with adjustable resistance.
Overhead tricep extension using cable machine with rope attachment. Provides constant tension throughout the movement for tricep development.
Preacher curl using cable machine. Combines preacher bench isolation with constant cable tension.
Reverse curl using cable machine with straight bar. Provides constant tension for forearm and brachioradialis development.
Russian twist using cable machine for constant tension. Provides consistent resistance throughout the rotational movement.
Seated horizontal row using cable machine. Provides constant tension throughout the movement with various handle attachments available.
Seated reverse fly using cable machine. Combines seated stability with constant cable tension for rear delt work.
Single arm bicep curl on cable machine. Provides constant tension while working each bicep independently.
Unilateral face pull on cable machine. Allows focus on each rear delt independently and helps correct imbalances.
Single arm lateral raise using cable machine. Provides constant tension while working each shoulder independently.
Unilateral lat pulldown on cable machine. Addresses strength imbalances and allows for greater lat stretch and contraction.

standard_name: Cable Single Arm Overhead Tricep Extension
description: Single arm overhead extension using cable machine. Provides constant tension while working each tricep independently.
Single arm row using cable machine. Provides constant tension throughout the movement with adjustable resistance.
Unilateral tricep pushdown on cable machine. Allows focus on each tricep independently and helps correct imbalances.
Single arm upright row using cable machine. Provides constant tension while working each side of shoulders and traps.
Standing single leg curl using ankle strap attached to a low cable pulley. Provides constant tension throughout the movement and allows for flexible positioning.
Tricep extension pushing cable attachment downward from high pulley. Staple tricep isolation exercise with various attachment options.
Upright row using cable machine. Provides constant tension throughout the movement for shoulder and trap development.
Lat pulldown with extra-wide grip. Maximizes lat stretch and emphasizes lat width development.

Sit on the floor with a foam roller under your calves. Support your weight with your hands behind you and lift your hips off the ground. Roll from just above your Achilles tendon to just below the back of your knee. Pause on tender spots. You can cross one leg over the other to increase pressure, or rotate your feet in and out to hit different parts of the calf. Avoid rolling directly over the Achilles tendon.

Sit on a chair or bench with a lacrosse ball under your calf. Cross your other leg on top to add pressure. You can make small movements or hold on tender spots. Move the ball around to different areas of your calf. This provides targeted deep tissue work. Avoid rolling directly over the Achilles tendon.

Stand with feet hip-width apart. Rise up onto your toes, lifting your heels as high as possible. Lower back down with control. Repeat in a smooth, controlled rhythm. This dynamically stretches and activates the calf muscles. You can hold onto a wall for balance if needed.

Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. For the "cat" position, round your spine toward the ceiling, tucking your chin and pelvis. For the "cow" position, arch your spine, lifting your chest and tailbone toward the ceiling. Flow between these two positions in a slow, controlled rhythm, coordinating with your breath. This mobilizes the entire spine but particularly benefits thoracic mobility.

Start on all fours. Flow through cat-cow (rounding and arching your spine), then press back into downward dog (hips up, forming an inverted V). Hold downward dog briefly, then return to all fours and repeat the sequence. This flows through multiple positions, mobilizing the entire spine, shoulders, and posterior chain.

Lie face down with a foam roller positioned vertically along your spine. Extend your arms out to the sides at shoulder height, palms down. Let gravity pull your arms toward the floor, stretching your chest. You can also place the roller horizontally and position it under one side of your chest at a time. Hold and breathe, allowing the chest to release.

Start on all fours, then sit your hips back toward your heels while extending your arms forward on the floor. Rest your forehead on the ground if comfortable. Allow your lower back to round and relax. You should feel a gentle stretch through your entire spine, particularly the lower back. Hold this position, breathing deeply into your back. This is a restorative stretch that releases tension.

Start in child's pose (sitting back on heels, arms extended forward). Walk both hands to one side, keeping your hips centered over your heels. You should feel a stretch along the opposite side of your torso and lat. Hold, then walk your hands to the other side. This provides an asymmetric lat stretch.

Sit or stand with good posture. Gently draw your chin straight back, creating a "double chin" without tilting your head up or down. Hold for a few seconds, then relax. This strengthens deep neck flexors and stretches the back of the neck. It's excellent for counteracting forward head posture from phone or computer use. This can be held or done as repetitions.

Lie on your side with hips and knees bent at 45 degrees, legs stacked. Keep your feet together and lift your top knee as high as you can without rotating your hips or torso. Your feet should stay touching throughout. Lower back down with control. You should feel this in the side of your hip and glute. Complete all reps on one side, then switch.

Stand in a corner facing the walls. Place your forearms on each wall with elbows at shoulder height. Lean forward into the corner until you feel a stretch across your chest and front of shoulders. Keep your core engaged and avoid arching your lower back. Hold this position, breathing deeply. This provides a deeper chest stretch than the doorway version.

Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width. Shift your weight to one side, squatting down on that leg while keeping the other leg straight with toes pointing up. Your squatting knee should track over your toes. Push back up and switch sides in one fluid motion. This is a deeper, more dynamic version of side lunges. Keep your chest up and core engaged.

Position yourself facing away from a couch or bench. Place one shin on the couch with your knee bent, foot pointing up. Step the other foot forward into a lunge position. Keep your torso upright - you should feel an intense stretch in the hip flexor and quad of your back leg. To increase the stretch, gently push your hips forward while keeping your core engaged. Hold, breathing deeply, then switch sides.

Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Extend both arms out to the sides at shoulder height. Swing both arms across your body, crossing them in front of your chest, then swing them back out wide. Alternate which arm crosses on top with each rep. Keep the movement smooth and controlled, gradually increasing range of motion.

Stand or sit tall. Bring one arm across your body at chest height. Use your opposite hand to gently pull the arm closer to your chest. Keep your shoulders down and avoid rotating your torso. You should feel the stretch in the back of your shoulder. Hold, then switch sides.
Cycling outdoors on roads or trails. Combines cardiovascular exercise with balance and navigation.
Cycling on a stationary bike. Provides low-impact cardiovascular exercise with adjustable resistance.

Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, arms fully extended. Let your body hang completely relaxed, allowing gravity to decompress your spine and stretch your lats and shoulders. Keep breathing normally. This is also excellent for grip strength and shoulder health. Start with shorter holds and build up duration.

Stand in a doorway with your forearm placed against the door frame, elbow bent at 90 degrees and positioned at shoulder height. Step forward with the foot on the same side as the stretched arm until you feel a stretch across your chest and front of shoulder. Keep your chest up and avoid rotating your torso. Hold the stretch, breathing deeply. Repeat on the other side.

Stand in a doorway and grab the frame with one hand at shoulder height or above. Step back and lean your hips away from the doorway while keeping your arm relatively straight. You should feel a stretch along the side of your torso and lat. Hold, then switch sides.

Stand in a doorway and place both forearms against the door frame at shoulder height, elbows bent at 90 degrees. Step forward until you feel a stretch across your upper back and between your shoulder blades. Keep your chest up and core engaged. Hold this position, breathing deeply. This helps counteract rounded upper back posture.

Start on all fours with hands slightly in front of shoulders. Push your hips up and back, straightening your legs as much as comfortable to form an inverted V shape with your body. Press your heels toward the floor (they don't need to touch) and keep your arms straight. You should feel a stretch in your hamstrings and calves. Hold this position, breathing deeply. You can pedal your feet to alternately stretch each leg.
Overhead press starting with palms facing you, rotating to palms forward at the top. Engages more of the shoulder through rotation, popularized by Arnold Schwarzenegger.
Reverse fly bent at the hips with dumbbells. Isolates rear delts and upper back with arc motion.
Bent over row with dumbbells. Allows for independent arm movement and natural hand positioning while targeting the back.
Bicep curl with dumbbells allowing independent arm movement. Can be performed simultaneously or alternating.
Bulgarian split squat performed while holding dumbbells at your sides. The most common loaded variation, allowing natural arm position and easier balance than barbell versions.
Seated single arm curl with elbow braced against inner thigh. Provides maximum bicep isolation with strict form.
Deadlift performed with dumbbells held at your sides. Allows for greater range of motion and natural hand positioning, making it more accessible for beginners or those with mobility limitations.
Decline press with dumbbells. Targets lower chest with independent arm movement and greater range of motion.
Chest fly on decline bench targeting lower chest. Emphasizes the lower pectorals with deep stretch and controlled movement.
Walking while carrying heavy dumbbells at your sides. Fundamental loaded carry building grip strength, trap development, and full-body stability.
Flat bench press with dumbbells. Allows for greater range of motion and independent arm movement, helping to address strength imbalances.
Chest fly on flat bench with dumbbells in an arc motion. Isolates the chest through horizontal adduction with deep stretch at the bottom.
Forward lunge with dumbbells held at your sides. The most common loaded lunge variation, allowing natural arm position and easy progression from bodyweight.
Front raise with dumbbells lifting weight forward to shoulder height. Isolates the front deltoids with control.
Glute bridge with dumbbell resting on hips. Accessible loaded variation for glute work when lying flat on the floor.
Squat performed while holding a dumbbell vertically at chest height. Excellent for teaching proper squat mechanics and maintaining an upright torso.
Bicep curl with neutral grip (palms facing each other). Targets the brachialis and brachioradialis in addition to biceps for complete arm development.
Incline press with dumbbells allowing natural arm movement. Excellent for upper chest development with greater range of motion than barbell.
Reverse fly lying chest-down on incline bench. Provides support and isolation for rear delts without lower back involvement.
Chest fly on incline bench targeting upper chest. Emphasizes the clavicular head of the pectorals with controlled arc motion.
Bicep curl performed on an incline bench with arms hanging back. Provides deep stretch and emphasizes the long head of the biceps.
Incline skullcrusher with dumbbells. Provides enhanced tricep stretch with independent arm movement on an incline bench.
Lateral lunge with dumbbells. Loads the lateral movement pattern to build strength in the often-neglected frontal plane while improving hip mobility.
Standing lateral raise with dumbbells. The classic side delt isolation exercise for building shoulder width and definition.
Overhead squat performed with dumbbells held overhead. Slightly easier to balance than barbell version and allows for independent arm movement.
Overhead extension with one or two dumbbells. Allows for natural arm path and can be performed with both arms or alternating.
Preacher curl with dumbbell allowing unilateral or bilateral work. Provides strict isolation of the biceps.
Push press with dumbbells using leg drive. Develops explosive shoulder strength and power with independent arm movement.
Reverse curl with dumbbells. Targets forearms and brachioradialis with independent arm movement.
Reverse lunge with dumbbells at your sides. Knee-friendly variation that allows for controlled descent and powerful drive back to standing.
Romanian deadlift with dumbbells at your sides. Allows for natural hand positioning and greater range of motion, making it easier to feel the hamstring stretch.
Russian twist holding dumbbell. Provides weighted resistance for rotational core and oblique strengthening.
Seal row with dumbbells lying prone on elevated bench. Removes lower back stress while allowing independent arm movement.
Seated overhead press with dumbbells. Allows for natural arm path and independent movement, helping to address shoulder imbalances.
Trap shrug with dumbbells at your sides. Allows natural arm position and greater range of motion than barbell.
Unilateral bicep curl with dumbbell. Allows full focus on one arm at a time and helps identify strength imbalances.
Unilateral front raise with dumbbell. Allows focus on each front delt independently and helps correct imbalances.
Unilateral lateral raise with dumbbell. Allows full focus on one shoulder at a time and helps identify imbalances.

standard_name: Dumbbell Single Arm Overhead Tricep Extension
description: Unilateral overhead extension with dumbbell. Isolates each tricep independently and helps identify strength imbalances.
Unilateral row with one hand supported on bench. Allows full range of motion and helps identify and correct strength imbalances.
Unilateral upright row with dumbbell. Allows focus on each side independently and helps identify imbalances.
Single leg hip thrust with dumbbell on hips. Easier to set up than barbell and effective for unilateral glute work.
Single leg RDL with dumbbell in one or both hands. The most accessible unilateral hip hinge variation, excellent for balance, stability, and isolating each leg.

standard_name: Dumbbell Single Leg Standing Calf Raise
description: Single leg calf raise holding a dumbbell. Requires balance and addresses strength imbalances between calves.
Lying tricep extension with dumbbells. Allows independent arm movement and natural hand positioning.
Standing calf raise holding dumbbells at your sides. Allows for natural arm position and easier balance than barbell variations.
Standing overhead press with dumbbells. Requires significant core stability and coordination while allowing natural shoulder movement.
Stiff leg deadlift with dumbbells held at your sides. Allows for greater range of motion and easier balance, making it accessible for targeting hamstring development.
Single-sided carry with weight in one hand like a suitcase. Heavily challenges core anti-lateral flexion and oblique stability.
Upright row with dumbbells. Allows natural hand positioning and independent arm movement.
Walking lunges with dumbbells at your sides. Excellent for building leg strength and endurance while challenging balance and stability with continuous movement.

Cross your right arm under your left at the elbows. Bend both elbows and try to bring your palms together (or backs of hands if that's more accessible). Lift your elbows slightly and move your hands away from your face to deepen the stretch. You should feel a stretch between your shoulder blades and in your shoulders. Hold, then switch which arm is on top.
Low-impact cardiovascular exercise on an elliptical machine. Provides smooth, joint-friendly motion.
Bicep curl using EZ curl bar with angled grip. Reduces wrist strain compared to straight bar while effectively targeting biceps.
Front raise with EZ bar. The angled grip provides a comfortable alternative to straight bar for front delt isolation.
Incline skullcrusher with EZ bar. Combines the wrist-friendly grip with enhanced tricep stretch from the incline angle.
Standing or seated overhead extension with EZ bar. The angled grip is easier on wrists while effectively targeting the long head of the triceps.
Preacher curl with EZ bar. The angled grip reduces wrist strain while maintaining strict bicep isolation.
Reverse curl with EZ bar. Angled grip reduces wrist strain while targeting forearms and brachioradialis.
Lying tricep extension with EZ bar. The angled grip reduces wrist and elbow strain while maintaining tricep effectiveness.
Upright row with EZ bar. The angled grip reduces wrist strain compared to straight bar while targeting shoulders and traps.

standard_name: EZ Bar Wide Grip Upright Row
description: Wide grip upright row with EZ bar. Combines shoulder-friendly wide grip with wrist-friendly angled bar.
Farmers walk using specialized farmer carry handles. Purpose-built equipment allowing for maximum loading and grip challenge.

Lie on your back with both knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Cross your right ankle over your left knee, creating a figure-4 shape with your legs. Reach through and clasp your hands behind your left thigh. Gently pull your left leg toward your chest until you feel a stretch in your right glute. Keep your head and shoulders relaxed on the floor. Hold, then switch sides.

Make a tight fist with one hand, then spread your fingers wide apart. Repeat in a smooth rhythm. This works the muscles of the hand and forearm. Switch hands and repeat. This is excellent for warming up the hands before gripping activities.

Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Keeping your knee bent at 90 degrees, lift one leg out to the side until your thigh is parallel to the ground (or as high as comfortable). Keep your hips level and avoid rotating your torso. Lower back down with control. Complete all reps on one side, then switch. Focus on using your glute to lift the leg.

Place a foam roller on a bench or elevated surface. Rest your forearm on the roller with palm facing down. Use your body weight to apply pressure and roll from your wrist to your elbow. You can rotate your forearm to hit different areas. Pause on tender spots. Switch to palm up to work the other side of your forearm. Switch arms and repeat.

Place a lacrosse ball on a table or bench. Rest your forearm on the ball with palm facing down. Apply pressure and make small movements or hold on tender spots. You can work up and down the forearm muscle. Rotate your forearm to work different areas. This provides targeted deep tissue work for the forearm muscles. Switch arms and repeat.

Bend your elbow at 90 degrees and hold it against your side. Rotate your forearm so your palm faces up (supination), then rotate it so your palm faces down (pronation). Move smoothly between these positions. This mobilizes forearm rotation. Switch arms and repeat.

Start on all fours and gradually widen your knees apart as far as comfortable, keeping your ankles in line with your knees. Lower down onto your forearms. You should feel a deep stretch in your inner thighs and groin. Rock gently forward and back or hold still. This is an intense stretch - start conservatively and breathe through it.

Stand with feet hip-width apart. Swing both arms forward and up as high as comfortable, then swing them back behind you. Keep arms relatively straight but not locked. Build momentum gradually and let the movement be controlled. This helps mobilize the shoulder joint through flexion and extension.

Lie on your back with arms extended out to the sides. Bend your right knee and let it fall across your body to the left side, twisting your spine. Your right shoulder should stay on the floor. Look to the right. You should feel a stretch through your entire spine, hip, and chest. Hold, then switch sides. This stretches multiple areas simultaneously.

Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart. Push through your heels to lift your hips off the ground until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to knees. Squeeze your glutes at the top. Lower back down with control. Avoid arching your lower back excessively - the movement should come from your glutes, not your spine.

Sit on a foam roller with one ankle crossed over the opposite knee (figure-4 position). Lean slightly toward the side of the crossed leg to target that glute. Rock back and forth slowly or make small circles. Pause on tender spots. Use your hands and supporting leg to control the pressure. Switch sides and repeat.

Sit on a lacrosse ball positioned on your glute. Cross the ankle of the side being worked over the opposite knee (figure-4 position) and lean into that side. You can stay still on tender spots or make small movements to work the area. Use your hands behind you to adjust pressure. This provides deeper, more targeted pressure than foam rolling. Switch sides and repeat.

Sit on the floor with a foam roller under your thighs. Support your weight with your hands behind you. Lift your hips off the ground and roll from just above the back of your knees to just below your glutes. Pause on tender spots. You can cross one leg over the other to increase pressure on one hamstring at a time, or work both legs together. Avoid rolling directly on the back of your knee.

Lie on your back and bring your knees toward your chest. Grab the outside edges of your feet (or behind your thighs if you can't reach) and gently pull your knees down toward your armpits. Keep your lower back on the floor and your head relaxed. You should feel a stretch in your hips, groin, and lower back. Hold this position, gently rocking side to side if desired.
Hiking on trails or mountainous terrain. Combines cardiovascular exercise with varied elevation and natural scenery.

Stand on one leg and lift the opposite knee to hip height. Make slow, controlled circles with your knee, moving from the hip joint. Complete all reps in one direction, then reverse. Switch legs and repeat. Keep your standing leg slightly bent and core engaged for balance. This mobilizes the hip joint through its full range of motion.

Stand with feet hip-width apart. Hinge at the hips and place your hands on the floor. Walk your hands forward into a plank position, then walk your feet toward your hands in small steps, keeping your legs as straight as possible. Stand up and repeat. This dynamically stretches the hamstrings while mobilizing the shoulders and warming up the entire body.

Lie on your side with the foam roller positioned under your outer thigh, between your hip and knee. Support your upper body with your forearm and place your top leg in front for stability. Roll slowly up and down the outer thigh, pausing on tender spots. Avoid rolling directly on the hip bone or knee. This is often uncomfortable - breathe through it and reduce pressure if needed by supporting more weight with your hands and top leg.
Jumping rope for cardiovascular exercise. High-intensity, portable workout emphasizing coordination and foot speed.
Bent over row with kettlebells. The offset weight distribution provides a unique grip challenge while building back strength.
Farmers walk with kettlebells. The unique handle position provides different grip demands while building functional strength.
Forward lunge with kettlebells. The unique weight distribution challenges grip and provides a different feel compared to dumbbells.
Squat performed while holding a kettlebell by the horns at chest height. The weight distribution naturally promotes proper squat form and torso positioning.
Lateral lunge with kettlebell. Can be held goblet-style at chest or at sides, providing a functional loading option for lateral strength development.
Push press with kettlebell using leg drive. The offset weight creates unique stability demands while building explosive overhead strength.
Reverse lunge holding kettlebells. Combines the knee-friendly reverse lunge pattern with kettlebell loading for a versatile leg exercise.
Unilateral row with kettlebell. The handle position provides a unique grip angle while working each side independently.
Single leg RDL with kettlebell. The offset weight distribution provides a unique stability challenge while developing unilateral posterior chain strength.
Standing overhead press with kettlebell. The offset weight distribution challenges stability and grip while developing functional pressing strength.
Unilateral carry with kettlebell. The offset weight distribution provides unique stability demands for core and grip.
Walking lunges holding kettlebells. The dynamic movement pattern combined with kettlebell loading builds functional leg strength and cardiovascular endurance.

Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat. Keeping knees and feet together, make slow circles with your knees, creating movement in your lower back and hips. Complete all reps in one direction, then reverse. Keep the movement controlled and within a comfortable range. This gently mobilizes the lower back.

Kneel on one knee with the other leg extended straight out to the side, foot flat on the ground and toes pointing forward. Keep your torso upright and shift your hips toward the extended leg side until you feel a stretch in your inner thigh. You can place hands on the floor for support. Hold, then switch sides.

Kneel on the floor with your toes tucked under (balls of feet on the ground, heels up). Sit back gently onto your heels to stretch the bottoms of your feet and front of your ankles. Keep your weight light - this can be intense. Hold the stretch, breathing deeply. To release, lean forward before untucking your toes. This stretches the ankle and plantar fascia.

Kneel on one knee with the other foot planted in front, knee bent at 90 degrees. Keep your torso upright and gently push your hips forward until you feel a stretch in the front of your back hip. Avoid arching your lower back - engage your core and slightly tuck your pelvis. For a deeper stretch, raise the arm on the same side as your back leg overhead and lean slightly away. Hold, then switch sides.

Kneel in front of a bench or elevated surface. Place your elbows or hands on the surface and sit your hips back toward your heels. Let your chest drop down toward the floor. You should feel a stretch in your lats and armpits. Hold this position, breathing deeply. You can walk your hands to one side to stretch that lat more intensely.

Kneel on one knee with the other foot planted in front. Reach back and grab the ankle of your kneeling leg, pulling your heel toward your glute. Keep your torso upright and core engaged. You should feel a stretch down the front of your thigh and hip. Hold, then switch sides. You can place a pad or towel under your knee for comfort.

Start on all fours with your fingers pointing toward your knees and palms flat on the floor. Gently rock back toward your heels to increase the stretch in your wrists and forearms. You should feel this along the underside of your forearms. Start gently as this can be intense. Hold, breathing deeply.

Lie on your back and bring both knees toward your chest. Hold behind your thighs or on top of your shins and gently pull your knees closer. Keep your lower back on the floor and your head and shoulders relaxed. You should feel a gentle stretch in your lower back and glutes. Hold this position, breathing deeply. This helps decompress the lumbar spine.
Single arm landmine row standing perpendicular to the bar, pulling across the body. Created by John Meadows, emphasizes lat stretch and contraction.
Single arm row using landmine attachment. The angled pulling path provides a unique stimulus for back development.
T-bar row using landmine attachment with V-handle or straddling the bar. Classic back builder allowing for heavy loads and thick back development.

Lie on your side with a foam roller positioned under your armpit/lat area. Extend your bottom arm overhead. Roll from your armpit down toward your mid-back. You can rotate slightly forward and back to hit different parts of the lat. Pause on tender spots. Support your weight with your top leg to adjust pressure. This can be uncomfortable - breathe through it. Switch sides and repeat.

Lie on your side with a lacrosse ball positioned under your armpit/lat area. Extend your bottom arm overhead. Apply pressure by relaxing into the ball. You can make small movements with your arm or hold on tender spots. This provides deeper, more targeted pressure than foam rolling. Adjust your position to work different areas of the lat. Switch sides and repeat.

Stand next to a wall or support for balance. Swing one leg forward and backward in a controlled manner, keeping it relatively straight. Start with small swings and gradually increase the range of motion. Avoid arching your lower back as you swing back. Keep your torso upright and core engaged. Complete all reps on one leg, then switch sides.

Stand facing a wall or support, holding on with both hands. Swing one leg side to side across your body, keeping it relatively straight. Start with small swings and gradually increase range of motion. Keep your hips and torso facing forward - avoid rotating. Your standing leg should be slightly bent. Complete all reps on one leg, then switch sides.

Sit or stand with good posture. Turn your head 45 degrees to one side, then tilt your nose down toward your armpit. You can place your hand on the back of your head for gentle added pressure. Keep the opposite shoulder down. You should feel a stretch along the back/side of your neck. Hold, then switch sides. This targets the levator scapulae muscle, which often gets tight from desk work.

Lie on your back with a lacrosse ball positioned beside your spine in the lower back area (not directly on the spine). Bend your knees with feet flat. You can stay still on tender spots or make small movements. The ball should be on the muscle beside the spine, not on the vertebrae themselves. Move the ball to different areas as needed. Be gentle with this area - use less pressure than you would for larger muscle groups.

Lie face down with one arm extended out to the side at shoulder height, palm down. Roll your body away from the extended arm, using your opposite hand to help you roll. You should feel a stretch across your chest and front of shoulder. You can bend your opposite knee and place that foot on the floor for stability. Hold, then switch sides.

Lie on your back with both knees bent and feet flat. Lift one leg and straighten it toward the ceiling, keeping the other foot flat on the floor. Hold behind your thigh and gently pull your leg toward your chest until you feel a stretch in your hamstring. Keep your leg as straight as comfortable and your head and shoulders relaxed on the floor. Hold, then switch legs.

Lie on your back with both legs extended. Loop a resistance band around one foot and hold the ends with both hands. Keeping your leg straight, use the band to gently pull your leg toward your chest until you feel a stretch in your hamstring. Keep your other leg flat on the floor and your head and shoulders relaxed. Hold, then switch legs. The band allows you to maintain the stretch with less effort.

Lie on your side with your bottom leg extended for stability. Bend your top knee and grab your ankle or foot, pulling your heel toward your glute. Keep your knees together and avoid arching your back. You can use your bottom arm under your head for support. Hold, then carefully switch to the other side.
Back extension on a 45-degree or horizontal hyperextension bench. Fundamental exercise for strengthening the lower back and posterior chain.
Bicep curl on a dedicated machine. Provides consistent resistance and easy weight selection for isolated bicep work.
Row on a chest-supported machine with torso braced against a pad. Isolates the back by eliminating lower back involvement and momentum.
Close grip lat pulldown on machine. Targets lower lats with narrow grip and consistent resistance.
Ab crunch on dedicated machine with adjustable resistance. Provides consistent loading and easy weight selection for ab isolation.
Decline chest press on a machine. Isolates the lower chest with guided movement pattern and easy weight adjustment.
Decline chest fly on machine. Isolates lower chest with guided motion and consistent resistance.
Chest press on a seated or plate-loaded machine. Provides guided motion and easy weight selection, excellent for beginners or isolation work.
Chest fly on a dedicated pec fly machine. Provides guided motion and easy weight selection for chest isolation.
Squat performed on a hack squat machine with back against a padded support and shoulders under pads. Isolates the legs while minimizing lower back involvement.
Hip thrust on a dedicated glute drive machine. Optimal back positioning and easy weight selection make this the most user-friendly hip thrust option.
Incline chest press on a machine. Isolates the upper chest with consistent resistance through the entire range of motion.
Incline chest fly on machine. Isolates upper chest with consistent resistance and controlled motion.
Lateral raise on a dedicated machine. Provides consistent resistance path and easy weight selection for shoulder isolation.
Lat pulldown on a plate-loaded or selectorized machine. Provides consistent resistance path for lat development.
Seated leg extension isolating the quadriceps through knee extension. Excellent for quad development, pre-exhaustion, or rehabilitation work with complete isolation from other muscle groups.

Seated leg press on a plate-loaded or selectorized machine. Allows for heavy loading of the legs with back support, making it excellent for building quad and glute strength with reduced lower back stress.
Lying face-down on a leg curl machine. The most common hamstring isolation exercise, allowing for focused hamstring development through knee flexion.
Overhead tricep extension on a dedicated machine. Provides consistent resistance and easy weight selection for tricep isolation.
Seated chest fly on pec deck machine with padded arms. Classic chest isolation exercise providing maximum stretch and contraction.
Preacher curl on a dedicated machine. Provides consistent resistance with arms supported for pure bicep isolation.
Reverse hyperextension on a dedicated machine, swinging legs upward while torso remains fixed. Provides traction to the spine while strengthening the lower back and glutes.
Seated calf raise with weight across the knees. Emphasizes the soleus muscle due to bent knee position, complementing standing calf work.
Seated good morning on a dedicated machine. Provides consistent resistance and back support, making it safer for lower back training.
Seated leg curl with thighs supported on a pad. The seated position pre-stretches the hamstrings, potentially allowing for greater muscle activation than lying variations.
Reverse fly on pec deck machine facing backward or dedicated rear delt machine. Provides supported isolation of rear delts.
Shoulder press on a dedicated machine. Provides consistent resistance and easy weight selection, excellent for shoulder isolation.
Unilateral curl on a machine. Isolates each bicep with consistent resistance path.
Single arm lat pulldown on machine. Isolates each lat independently with consistent resistance.
Unilateral row on a dedicated machine. Provides consistent resistance and easy weight selection for isolated back work.
Unilateral leg extension working one leg at a time. Allows for focused quad development and helps identify strength imbalances between legs.
Unilateral leg press working one leg at a time. Identifies and corrects strength imbalances while requiring greater core stability than bilateral leg press.

standard_name: Machine Single Leg Standing Calf Raise
description: Unilateral standing calf raise on a machine. Identifies and corrects strength imbalances while allowing each calf to work through its full range independently.
Standing calf raise on a dedicated machine with shoulder pads for resistance. Most common calf exercise, allowing for heavy loading and full range of motion.
Standing unilateral leg curl on a dedicated machine. Works one leg at a time while requiring balance and stability, helping to identify and correct imbalances.
T-bar row on a dedicated machine with chest support. Allows heavy loading while minimizing lower back stress.
Wide grip lat pulldown on machine. Fixed path allows focus on lat contraction with wide grip positioning.
Russian twist holding medicine ball for added resistance. Increases rotational strength and oblique development.

Sit or stand with good posture. Slowly tilt your head forward, bringing your chin toward your chest, then tilt it back to look up at the ceiling. Move in a smooth, controlled motion. Avoid forcing the end ranges. This mobilizes the neck through flexion and extension.

Lie on your back and place a lacrosse ball at the base of your skull or along the side of your neck where it meets your shoulder (upper trap area). Apply gentle pressure and you can make small head movements or hold on tender spots. Be very gentle with the neck area - use light pressure. Never place the ball directly on your spine. This releases tension in the suboccipital muscles and upper traps.

Sit or stand with good posture. Slowly tilt your head to one side, bringing your ear toward your shoulder. Return to center, then tilt to the other side. Keep your shoulders down and relaxed - don't lift your shoulder to meet your ear. Move smoothly and controlled. This mobilizes lateral flexion of the cervical spine.

Sit or stand with good posture. Slowly roll your head in a circular motion, letting it fall gently forward, to one side, back, to the other side, and forward again. Complete all reps in one direction, then reverse. Move slowly and avoid forcing the movement. Skip this if it causes dizziness or pain. This mobilizes the cervical spine through its full range of motion.

Sit or stand with good posture. Slowly turn your head to look over one shoulder, then return to center and turn to look over the other shoulder. Keep your shoulders facing forward - only your head should rotate. Move smoothly and don't force the end range. This mobilizes neck rotation.

Stand or sit tall. Reach both arms overhead and grab your left wrist with your right hand. Gently pull your left arm up and to the right, creating a side bend. You should feel a stretch along the left side of your torso and lat. Keep your hips facing forward. Hold, then switch sides.

Lie on your back with two lacrosse balls taped together (creating a "peanut" shape) or a peanut massage tool positioned vertically along your spine in the upper back area. The balls should be on either side of your spine, not directly on it. You can stay still or make small movements. This provides targeted release for muscles along the thoracic spine. Move the balls to different levels of your upper back.

Stand facing a wall or lie face down on the floor with a lacrosse ball positioned on your pec muscle (below the collarbone, above the armpit area). Apply gentle pressure and you can make small movements with your arm or hold on tender spots. Avoid placing the ball directly on the collarbone or shoulder joint. This releases tension in the pec muscles. Switch sides and repeat.

Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Tilt your pelvis to flatten your lower back against the floor (posterior tilt), then arch slightly to create a small gap under your lower back (anterior tilt). Move slowly and controlled between these positions. This mobilizes the lumbar spine and helps develop awareness of pelvic position.

Start on all fours. Bring your right knee forward and place it behind your right wrist, with your shin angled under your body. Extend your left leg straight back behind you. Square your hips to the front and lower down onto your forearms or all the way to the floor if comfortable. You should feel a deep stretch in your right glute and hip. Hold, breathing deeply, then switch sides. This is an intense stretch - start gently.
Back extension holding a weight plate against chest. Easy way to add progressive resistance to back extensions with simple setup.
Crunch holding weight plate against chest. Adds resistance for progressive overload on ab development.
Decline crunch with weight plate for added resistance. Combines increased range of motion with progressive loading.
Front raise holding a weight plate. Simple and effective front delt exercise with easy grip and setup.
Russian twist with weight plate for progressive overload. Builds rotational core strength with easily adjustable resistance.

Place your palms together in front of your chest in a prayer position, fingers pointing up. Keep your palms pressed together and slowly lower your hands toward your waist, keeping your elbows out to the sides. You should feel a stretch in your wrists and forearms. Hold this position. The lower you go, the more intense the stretch.

Lie face down with your hands placed under your shoulders. Press through your hands to lift your chest off the ground, focusing on extending through your mid-back. Keep your hips on the ground and elbows slightly bent. Look forward or slightly up. Hold this position, then lower back down. This improves thoracic extension, which is often limited from desk work.

Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Walk your hands forward, lowering your chest toward the ground while keeping your hips stacked over your knees. Rest your forehead on the floor if comfortable. Press your chest down toward the floor to deepen the shoulder stretch. Your arms should be straight. Hold this position, breathing deeply into the stretch.

Lie face down with the foam roller under your thighs, supporting your weight on your forearms. Roll from just above your knees to just below your hips. Pause on tender spots. You can rotate your legs in and out slightly to hit different parts of the quad. To increase pressure on one leg, cross the other leg over it. This can be intense - breathe through it and reduce pressure if needed.

Lie face down with a lacrosse ball positioned under your quad. Support your weight on your forearms and opposite leg. Apply pressure by relaxing into the ball. You can make small movements or hold on tender spots. Move the ball to different areas of your quad to address tight spots. This provides deeper, more targeted pressure than foam rolling.

Stand with your back against a wall with a lacrosse ball positioned on the back of your shoulder (rear delt area). Apply pressure by leaning into the wall. You can make small movements or hold on tender spots. To increase pressure, step your feet slightly away from the wall. Move the ball to different spots around the back of your shoulder to address tight areas. Breathe deeply and avoid holding your breath.

Lie on your back and bring the soles of your feet together, letting your knees fall out to the sides. Let your arms rest out to the sides or overhead. Relax completely, allowing gravity to open your hips and chest. This is a restorative stretch that opens the entire front of the body. Hold for an extended period, breathing deeply.
Diamond pushup with resistance band for added difficulty. Combines close-hand positioning with variable resistance for advanced tricep development.
Pushup with resistance band across the back providing additional resistance. Increases difficulty with variable resistance peaking at the top of the movement.
Wide grip pushup with resistance band. Combines enhanced chest engagement with progressive resistance.

Place the backs of your hands together behind your back with fingers pointing down. Slowly raise your hands up your back while keeping the backs of your hands together. You should feel a stretch in your wrists and forearms. Hold this position. This is more advanced and may not be accessible for everyone.
Rowing on an indoor rowing machine (e.g., Concept2). Full-body cardiovascular exercise emphasizing pulling motion.
Rowing in a boat on water. Combines cardiovascular exercise with balance and technique on open water.
Running outdoors on roads, trails, or tracks. Natural terrain and weather conditions provide varied challenges.
Running on a treadmill. Allows for controlled pace and incline settings in a climate-controlled environment.
Back squat using a safety squat bar with padded shoulder rests and forward-angled handles. Reduces stress on shoulders and wrists while maintaining squat benefits.
Box squat using a safety squat bar. Combines the benefits of box squatting with reduced shoulder and wrist stress from the specialized bar.
Good morning using a safety squat bar. The forward-angled weight distribution increases difficulty while reducing shoulder and wrist stress.

Start in a plank or elevated plank position (hands on bench if needed). Keep your arms completely straight and locked. Without bending your elbows, let your chest sink down between your shoulder blades, allowing your shoulder blades to come together. Then push your upper back toward the ceiling, spreading your shoulder blades apart. The movement is small and comes entirely from the shoulder blades, not the elbows.

Lie face down with arms extended out to the sides. Keeping your chest and arms on the floor, lift your right leg and swing it across your body toward your left hand, rotating through your spine. Return to start and repeat on the other side. Keep the movement controlled. This mobilizes the hips and spine while stretching the anterior chain.

Sit in a chair with one foot flat on the ground. Keep your heel down and lift the ball of your foot and toes up as high as possible, then lean your knee forward over your toes. You should feel a stretch in the front of your shin and ankle. Hold, then switch ankles. This improves ankle dorsiflexion, which is important for squatting and running.

Sit on the floor with one leg extended straight. Loop a towel or your hands around the ball of your foot. Keeping your leg straight, gently pull your toes toward you until you feel a stretch in your calf. Keep your knee straight but not locked. Hold, then switch legs.

Sit on the floor with one leg extended straight. Loop a resistance band around the ball of your foot and hold the ends. Keeping your leg straight, use the band to gently pull your toes toward you until you feel a stretch in your calf. The band provides consistent tension. Hold, then switch legs.

Sit on the floor with knees bent and feet flat. Place your hands on the floor behind you, fingers pointing away from your body. Gently press your chest forward and up while squeezing your shoulder blades together. You should feel a stretch across your chest. Keep your neck neutral. Hold this position, breathing deeply.

Sit on the floor with both legs extended straight in front of you. Hinge forward at the hips, reaching toward your toes. Keep your back as straight as possible - the stretch should come from your hip hinge, not from rounding your spine. You should feel a stretch in your hamstrings and lower back. Hold, breathing deeply. You can bend your knees slightly if needed.

Sit in a chair with feet flat on the floor. Cross your right ankle over your left knee. Keeping your back straight, lean forward from your hips until you feel a stretch in your right glute. You can gently press down on your right knee to increase the stretch. Hold, then switch sides. This is a more accessible version of the figure-4 stretch.

Sit on the floor with one leg extended straight and the other leg bent with the sole of your foot against your inner thigh. Keep your back straight and hinge forward at the hips, reaching toward the toes of your extended leg. You should feel the stretch in the back of your extended leg. Avoid rounding your spine. Hold, then switch legs.

Sit with good posture. Interlace your fingers behind your head. Gently tuck your chin and use your hands to guide your head forward and down, bringing your chin toward your chest. Keep your shoulders relaxed. You should feel a stretch along the back of your neck and upper back. Hold this position, breathing deeply.

Sit on the floor with legs extended. Bend your right knee and cross it over your left leg, placing your right foot flat on the floor outside your left knee. Place your right hand on the floor behind you. Twist your torso to the right, using your left elbow against your right knee to deepen the twist. Keep your spine tall. Hold, then switch sides. This stretches the entire spine with emphasis on thoracic rotation.

Sit on the floor with legs spread wide in a V shape. Sit up tall and hinge forward from your hips, walking your hands forward on the floor. Keep your back as straight as possible. You should feel a stretch in your inner thighs. You can also reach toward one foot at a time to stretch that side more intensely. Hold in whichever position you choose.

Stand with feet hip-width apart and arms relaxed at your sides. Slowly lift your shoulders up toward your ears, then roll them back and down in a circular motion. Complete all reps in one direction, then reverse. Keep the movement smooth and controlled, focusing on the full range of motion.

Stand with feet hip-width apart. Reach one arm overhead and lean to the opposite side, feeling a stretch along the side of your torso. Return to center and repeat on the other side. Move in a controlled rhythm. Avoid leaning forward or back - the bend should be directly to the side. This stretches the lats and obliques.

Stand with feet wide apart. Shift your weight to one side, bending that knee while keeping the other leg straight. Push your hips back as you lower down. You should feel a stretch in the inner thigh of your straight leg. Push back to center and repeat on the other side. Keep your chest up and heels down throughout. This dynamically stretches the adductors.

Lie on your back with one leg extended and the other knee bent. Pull the bent knee toward your chest, holding behind your thigh. Keep your extended leg relaxed on the floor and your lower back pressed down. Hold, then switch legs. This provides a gentler lower back stretch than the double knee version and allows you to work each side independently.

Lie on your side with the bottom arm extended straight out at shoulder height. Bend your elbow to 90 degrees so your hand points toward the ceiling. Using your top hand, gently push your bottom hand down toward the floor, rotating your shoulder internally. Keep your shoulder blade pinned to the floor. You should feel a stretch in the back of your shoulder. Hold, then switch sides.
Back squat performed on a Smith machine with a fixed vertical bar path. Provides stability and allows for focused leg development with reduced balance requirements.
Bent over row on Smith machine. Fixed bar path allows focus on pulling motion without worrying about bar stability.
Box squat performed on a Smith machine. The guided bar path allows for aggressive sitting back onto the box with reduced balance concerns.
Bulgarian split squat performed on a Smith machine. The guided bar path reduces balance demands, allowing focus on leg drive and higher loading with less risk.

standard_name: Smith Machine Close Grip Bench Press
description: Close grip bench press on Smith machine. Fixed bar path allows focus on tricep and inner chest development without balance concerns.
Conventional deadlift on a Smith machine with fixed vertical bar path. Reduces balance and stabilization requirements, allowing focus on the posterior chain movement pattern.
Decline bench press on Smith machine. The fixed bar path allows focus on lower chest development with stable pressing.
Deficit deadlift on a Smith machine from an elevated platform. The guided bar path maintains form through the extended range of motion while building strength off the floor.
Bench press on a Smith machine with fixed bar path. Reduces stabilization demands, allowing focus on pressing strength and muscle isolation.
Forward lunge on a Smith machine. The guided bar path reduces balance requirements, allowing focus on leg drive and depth.
Front squat performed on a Smith machine. The fixed bar path allows focus on leg drive without balance concerns, making it easier to maintain an upright position.
Glute bridge on Smith machine lying flat on floor. Fixed bar path makes setup and execution straightforward for loaded glute bridges.
Hip thrust on a Smith machine with fixed bar path. Provides stability and consistent resistance, making setup easier than free barbell.
Incline bench press on Smith machine. Fixed path makes it easier to target the upper chest without worrying about bar stability.
Pendlay row on Smith machine starting each rep from pins or floor. Fixed path allows focus on explosive pulling power.
Reverse lunge on a Smith machine. The fixed bar path provides stability, making it easier to maintain an upright torso and focus on depth.
Romanian deadlift on a Smith machine with fixed bar path. Excellent for focusing on the hip hinge pattern and hamstring stretch without balance concerns.
Seated shoulder press on Smith machine. Fixed vertical path reduces stabilization demands for focused shoulder development.
Trap shrug on Smith machine. Fixed vertical path allows focus on pure trap contraction without bar control concerns.

standard_name: Smith Machine Single Leg Hip Thrust
description: Unilateral hip thrust on Smith machine. The fixed path provides stability for single leg work while allowing focus on each glute.
Snatch grip shrug on Smith machine. Combines wide grip range of motion with fixed bar path for consistent trap work.
Standing calf raise on a Smith machine. The fixed bar path provides stability, allowing for heavier loading with reduced balance concerns.
Stiff leg deadlift on a Smith machine with guided bar path. Removes balance component, allowing lifters to focus purely on the hamstring stretch and hip hinge pattern.
Sumo stance deadlift on a Smith machine. The fixed bar path allows lifters to focus on hip drive and leg strength without worrying about the bar drifting forward.
Upright row on Smith machine. Fixed vertical path allows focus on the pulling motion without bar control concerns.

Lie face down with forearms on the floor, elbows under shoulders. Press through your forearms to lift your chest, creating a gentle backbend. Keep your hips and legs relaxed on the floor. This creates gentle extension in the lower back. Hold this position, breathing deeply. This is a gentle way to improve lumbar extension and can help relieve tension from prolonged sitting.
Climbing stairs on a stair climber machine. Emphasizes lower body engagement with cardiovascular benefits.
Ab wheel rollout from standing position. Extremely advanced variation requiring exceptional core strength and control.

Stand with feet hip-width apart. Place your hands on your lower back for support. Gently lean backward, extending through your lower back. Keep your knees soft and core engaged. Only go as far as comfortable - this should feel like a gentle stretch, not painful. Hold briefly, then return to standing. This helps counteract forward-bending postures.

Stand facing a wall with hands against it for support. Step one leg back and slightly bend the back knee while keeping your heel on the ground. Lean forward gently until you feel a stretch lower in your calf, near the Achilles tendon. This targets the soleus (lower calf). Hold, then switch legs.

Stand facing a wall with hands against it for support. Step one leg back, keeping it straight with your heel on the ground. Bend your front knee and lean forward until you feel a stretch in the calf of your back leg. Keep your back heel down and toes pointing forward. This targets the gastrocnemius (upper calf). Hold, then switch legs.

Hold a resistance band behind your back with both hands, arms straight. Gently pull the band apart and lift your chest up, feeling the stretch across your pecs. Keep your shoulders down and back. The band provides constant tension for a sustained stretch. Hold this position, adjusting the width of your hands to change the intensity.

Stand and place one heel on an elevated surface (bench, step, or low table) with your leg straight and toes pointing up. Keep your standing leg slightly bent. Hinge forward at the hips, keeping your back straight, until you feel a stretch in your hamstring. Avoid rounding your spine - the stretch should come from your hip hinge. Hold, then switch legs.

Stand with feet hip-width apart. Shift your weight to one leg and extend the other leg straight in front of you with toes pointed up. Hinge forward at the hips, reaching toward your toes while keeping your back straight. Return to standing and repeat in a smooth, controlled motion. Complete all reps on one leg, then switch. This dynamically stretches the hamstring through movement.

Stand with feet together. Cross your right leg behind your left. Lean your upper body to the left while pushing your right hip out to the right side. You should feel a stretch along the outside of your right hip and thigh. You can reach your right arm overhead and to the left to deepen the stretch. Hold, then switch sides. Keep both feet flat on the ground.

Stand on one leg (use a wall for balance if needed). Bend your other knee and grab your ankle or foot behind you. Pull your heel toward your glute, keeping your knees close together. Keep your torso upright and avoid arching your lower back. Push your hips slightly forward to increase the stretch. Hold, then switch legs.

Lie on your back. Cross your right ankle over your left knee (figure-4). Pull your left knee toward your chest, clasping behind the thigh. You should feel a stretch in your right glute.
