For an added stretch, you can also let your left knee fall to the right, creating a twist. Hold, then switch sides.

Lie on your back with arms extended out to the sides. Bend one knee and let it fall across your body to the opposite side, twisting your spine. Keep your shoulders flat on the floor. You can use your opposite hand to gently guide your knee closer to the floor. Look in the opposite direction of your knee. Hold, then switch sides. This stretches the lower back and outer hip.
Swimming laps or treading water. Provides full-body, low-impact cardiovascular exercise.

Start on all fours. Rotate your hands so your fingers point toward your knees (backs of hands on the floor). Gently rock back slightly to increase the stretch in your wrists and forearms. This can be intense - start gently and only go as far as comfortable. Hold, breathing deeply. This stretches the wrist extensors in a weight-bearing position.

Start on all fours. Place one hand behind your head. Rotate your upper body, bringing your elbow down toward the opposite arm, then rotate up and open toward the ceiling, following your elbow with your eyes. Keep your hips stable - the rotation should come from your mid-back. Complete all reps on one side, then switch. This is excellent for thoracic spine mobility.

Lie on your back with a foam roller positioned horizontally under your mid-back (shoulder blade area). Cross your arms over your chest or place hands behind your head to support your neck. Lift your hips and roll up and down your upper back. You can pause at tender spots or extend back over the roller to increase the stretch. Do not roll on your lower back or neck - stay in the mid-back region only.

Start on all fours. Reach one arm underneath your body, threading it through the space between your other arm and knee. Your shoulder and ear should rest on the floor. Return to the starting position and repeat in a controlled motion. Complete all reps on one side, then switch. This stretches the upper back and shoulder while improving thoracic rotation.
Deadlift performed inside a hexagonal trap bar with neutral grip handles. More quad involvement and reduced lower back stress compared to barbell deadlifts, with easier setup position.
Farmers walk inside trap bar. Allows for heavier loading with balanced weight distribution and comfortable grip position.
Shrug inside trap bar with neutral grip. Allows for heavy loading with comfortable hand position and better balance.
Inverted row using suspension straps. The instability increases core engagement while targeting back muscles.

Lie on your back with a foam roller positioned under your upper back/shoulder blade area. Cross your arms over your chest or place hands behind your head. Lift your hips off the ground and use your legs to roll back and forth over the upper back area. Pause on tender spots. This helps release tension that affects shoulder mobility. Keep your core engaged and avoid rolling directly on your spine or lower back.

Sit or stand with good posture. Tilt your head to one side, bringing your ear toward your shoulder. For a deeper stretch, place your hand on the same side on top of your head and apply gentle pressure. Keep the opposite shoulder down. You should feel a stretch along the side of your neck and top of your shoulder. Hold, then switch sides.
Walking outdoors on sidewalks, paths, or trails. Accessible, low-impact cardiovascular exercise.

While walking forward slowly, reach back and grab your right ankle with your right hand, pulling your heel toward your glute. Take a few steps while holding, then release and repeat on the left side. Keep your knees close together and avoid arching your lower back. This is great for warming up before activity.
Walking on a treadmill. Low-impact cardiovascular exercise with controlled pace and incline settings.

standard_name: Wall Calf Stretch with Toe Elevated
description: Stand facing a wall and place the ball of one foot against the wall with your heel on the ground, creating an angle with your foot. Keep your leg straight and lean forward slightly until you feel a stretch in your calf. This provides a deep stretch through the entire calf and Achilles. Hold, then switch legs.

Stand with your back against a wall. Bring your arms up with elbows bent at 90 degrees, backs of hands against the wall. Slide your arms up overhead while maintaining contact with the wall, then slide back down. Move slowly and keep your lower back from arching excessively. This mobilizes the chest and shoulders while promoting good posture.
Captain's chair leg raise with additional weight. Advanced variation for increased core strength development.
Chin up with additional weight. Combines bicep and back development with progressive loading for advanced strength.
Bodyweight dip with additional weight attached via belt or chain. Progressive overload for advanced lifters to continue building chest and tricep strength.
Hanging leg raise with additional weight attached. Advanced progression for building exceptional core strength.
Neutral grip pullup with additional weight. Combines shoulder-friendly hand position with progressive loading for back development.
Pullup with additional weight attached via belt or chain. Progressive overload for advanced athletes to continue building back strength.
Wide grip pullup with added weight. Advanced lat width builder for athletes who have mastered bodyweight wide grip pullups.
Decline pushup with weighted vest. Combines elevated foot position with added resistance for advanced upper chest development.
Diamond pushup with weighted vest. Adds consistent resistance to this tricep-focused pushup variation.
Plank with weighted vest for added resistance. Increases difficulty and core strength demands of the isometric hold.
Pushup wearing a weighted vest. Provides consistent added resistance throughout the movement for progressive overload.
Side plank with weighted vest. Advanced oblique and lateral core strengthening with additional resistance.
Wide grip pushup with weighted vest. Increases loading on the chest with wider hand placement.

Stand with feet wide apart, toes pointing forward or slightly out. Hinge forward at the hips, keeping your back straight, and reach your hands toward the floor. You can rest your hands on the floor, shins, or a block. You should feel a stretch in your inner thighs and hamstrings. Keep your knees soft and avoid rounding your spine excessively. Hold, breathing deeply.

Start in a plank position. Step your right foot outside your right hand into a deep lunge. Drop your back knee if needed. Place your left hand on the floor and rotate your torso to the right, reaching your right arm toward the ceiling. Return your right hand to the floor, lift your hips up to straighten your front leg (feeling a hamstring stretch), then return to the lunge. Step back to plank and repeat on the other side. This comprehensive movement stretches hips, hamstrings, and thoracic spine.

Extend one arm in front of you. Make circles with your hand, rotating at the wrist. Complete all reps in one direction, then reverse. Switch arms and repeat. Keep the movement smooth and controlled, working through the full range of motion. This mobilizes the wrist joint.

Extend one arm in front of you with palm facing down. Use your other hand to gently pull your fingers down and back toward your body. Keep your elbow straight. You should feel a stretch along the top of your forearm. Hold, then switch arms. This stretches the wrist extensors, which often get tight from computer work.

Extend one arm in front of you with palm facing down. Bend your wrist to point your fingers toward the floor (flexion), then bend it to point your fingers toward the ceiling (extension). Move smoothly between these positions. Switch arms and repeat. This mobilizes the wrist through its primary plane of motion.

Extend one arm in front of you with palm facing up. Use your other hand to gently pull your fingers down and back toward your body. Keep your elbow straight. You should feel a stretch along the underside of your forearm. Hold, then switch arms. This stretches the wrist flexors.
